column2: witty
column3: intelligent
column4: charming

column1: ...until I got home. Work was an escape from myself for me. If I had no weekend functions to attend I would be catatonic
column2: only getting out of bed to use the bathroom.

column1: I had always felt like an outsider
column2: looking in on life
column3: trying to imitate what everyone else was doing
column4: but never getting it quite right and others sensing that I was a fake.

column1: I retired in Jan '17. Not having work as an escape anymore
column2: in Dec my depression got again very bad. I talked to my girlfriend and she recommended sertraline as it has helped her. On 5 Jan
column3: I saw the doctor
column4: she prescribed 25mg as a started dose for 8 days
column5: then 50mg
column6: with a follow up 6 weeks later to see if the dose would need to be increased.

column2: wake/sleep cycle issues
column3: decreased appetite
column4: jaw tightness and jittery feeling initially. I experimented with taking my dose at night because it seemed that immediately after taking it
column5: I had to go back to sleep. Taking it at night then kept me up. So I went back to taking it in the morning
column6: as I figured it was a matter of me getting used to the med.

column2: but it seems like a lifetime ago.  The anxiety subsided first
column3: then my depression. I no longer think of the smallest thing as the greatest catastrophe
column4: my thoughts are no longer chasing around in my head like a bunch of squirrels and I am off the emotional roller coaster.  Thoughts from my past no longer send me into apoplexy.

column1: I no longer feel like a walking dead person-dead on the inside
column2: waiting for physical death to catch up with me. No not suicidal-many years ago I came to the realization that I can only live once for a limited amount of time
column3: but death is forever. Also
column4: as long as I was alive
column5: I always had a choice
column6: but once I was dead
column7: there was no coming back."

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$3$4$"There is a difference between sertraline and Zoloft (generic vs. brand name). Not all sertraline manufacturers are the same. column3: I started waking up with severe anxiety a few mornings/week. I feel like something terrible is going to happen and had to take an inventory of what's going on for the day so I could calm down.I have breakthrough depression where I'm depressed for twenty minutes or so
column4: then it just disappears for days. I get really tired but have trouble sleeping. I also get shooting pains through the side of my head and more ""regular"" headaches on top of my typical migraines. I've checked on this and there are issues with the generic. I'm going to see if I can switch to the original Zoloft or ask Walgreens to change manufacturers. Look up your manufacturer
column5: check out other people's experiences and print it out to show your doc if you need to. We all know that some don't like to listen to patients. The first generic manufacturer was green-something. I did get an *extremely* dry mouth and eyes
column6: but after a few months it got better."

column7: starting on torso
column8: spreading from chin to ankles. In next week or 2 developed blisters over entire body
column9: covering nearly every sq. inch. Very painful. couldn't sleep . This is now July. Most blisters have gone. Some scabbing remains with a few open sores. The result was a condition called Bullous pemphigoid
column10: a rare skin condition. Although I'm sure that many people will tolerate this drug
column11: I can only suggest that they proceed with caution and stop it at the first sign of side effects. This is the worst condition I have ever experienced. Docs also mentioned that this is more common in people over 60.

19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I switched from Lexapro to Zoloft about a year ago and it has worked very well for me.  The only down sides to it are slight weight gain and lessened sex drive but considering it pretty much got rid of my manic depression and anxiety it is worth sacrificing those two things.

column1: One note:  for about the first two weeks you take it you will have moderate to severe nausea
column2: or at least I did.  It passes though so don't stop taking it.  It also occurs again if you forget to take a couple of doses (as well as your symptoms coming back...).

Zoloft may change the way you taste things.  I used to smoke but after about a month of zoloft the taste of cigarettes made me instantly sick to my stomach and eventually so did the smell of the smoke (I guess this is a good thing though).

if your depression/anxiety was causing you not to have a good nights rest you will have the best sleep of your life on Zoloft but for first month or so be sure to schedule at least 8 hours for sleep or else you will wake up lethargic. "

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I've been taking Sertraline/Zoloft for 5 years to treat depression.

column1: I started at 25mg then to 50mg where I stayed for 3 years.

After a divorce I moved to 100mg for obvious reasons. For at least a year it seemed to do very well with crying episodes and overall getting through the divorce. Around the year mark the depression became much worse and I was extremely lethargic. I lost interest in everything
column2: including friends and family. I wouldn't go on dates and it was all I could do to go to work. The odd thing was that I seemingly had everything a single person would want. A lake house
column3: nice car
column4: great job and my choice of who I wanted to date.

column2: people close to me had no idea that I became a recluse. They all assumed I was having the time of my life.

column1: One morning I woke up and felt that I just couldn't take the pain anymore. I went to the kitchen
column2: leaned over the sink with a large knife to my throat. While trying to decide if it would be better to instead cut my wrist
column3: I stopped and called my doctor. I was surprised to hear her say to come right away to see her. When I drove to her office I was crying my eyes out because I hated who I had become. Thankfully my Dr didn't give up on me and actually up'd my dosage to 200mg. It honestly saved my life. I soon became depression free with the only side effect of still being lethargic. Also the dizzy brain zaps when I miss a dose.

column2: but always tired. My Dr. Has put me on a new medicine called Fetzima 20mg and has cut the Zoloft back to 100mg to help with the tiredness. So far so good after 3 weeks. I went through a few dizzy spells
column3: but stuck with it and feel like my old self again.

column1: If you or anyone you know has secluded themselves please know that there is hope.
The first step is having someone who understands your sickness and that you don't choose to feel this way.
The second step and hardest thing to do IMO is finding and then giving the medicine time to work.

661$Depression$11/19/2014 10:55:05 PM$Reviewer: Happy Enough, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$3$5$Zoloft was like a miracle pill for me.  My moodiness, irritability, sadness, and anxiousness are much more controlable and I feel like I can cope with life now.  However, it is not without side-effects.  The first 3 weeks I had diarrhea and headaches, but not major enough to stop trying it.  After a month, the cloud lifted and I started enjoying life again.  Six months later, though, other side effects such as loss of libido crept in.  I have never had a problem maintaining my weight, and have always had a fast metabolism. After  18 months on this drug I have gained 15 pounds (all within the last 6 months).  So, it's a tradeoff.  Life is not perfect, but it's good...

710$Depression$4/24/2014 4:42:23 PM$Reviewer: Kate, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I have struggled with an eating disorder, anxiety and very bad depression with suicidal thoughts for 4+ years. When I got to my lowest point I decided to try anti-depressants. Like most people, I was afraid that it would make me numb, emotionless, etc, but that didn't happen at all. I started out with 50mg a day. Once I had been taking them for a few weeks I already felt a difference in how I look at myself and other people (my family and boyfriend) noticed it too. Several months into taking Zoloft I hit a plateau. When I told my doctor that, she said that was very normal and upped my dosage to 100mg. The only negative side effect I have experienced is the night sweats ONCE IN A WHILE. Yes, they are uncomfortable and it's annoying to wake up feeling cold, but really clammy and sweaty, but the positive effects of the drug outweigh the negative sides in my opinion. My depression also interfered with my sleeping pattern. I would go through a couple days to a week or more of being so fatigued ALL the time and sleeping way more than I should, and then other times where I am so restless that I continuously toss and turn in bed and finally give up and just stay up all night. So, my doctor prescribed me Trazodone (helps with insomnia and is an anti-depressant) to take along with Zoloft. These two drugs together have worked very well for me regarding general depression symptoms, anxiety, insomnia, disordered eating, etc. 
711$Depression$4/22/2014 11:18:02 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$1$5$I was given this drug in order to deal with the death of my fiance. Once I took it, I was emotionless. I could not cry to save my life. That is not how I want to feel. I need to release this hurt and now it is being blocked. I feel strange. I know that the need to cry is there, but by it being trapped, it is making me anxious and jittery. I am able to sleep, but when I awaken, I feel distant. I feel like my body is not mine. I am not sure what the intended effect of this medication is suppose to be, but I do not like the way it makes me feel. I was given 50mg and told to start off with 1/2 (25mg). The 25mg seems to be too much for me. The day of the funeral, I know I was being looked at because of my lack of tears. They just would not come out. I was like a zombie going through the motions. I am trying to get a hold of someone to see whether or not I am able to get on something more balancing. I feel as though I am about to have a panic attack.

1014$Depression$6/21/2012 12:21:40 PM$Reviewer: ZoloftOKwithme, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I've been on & off this med since 2007; it worked pretty well but had sexual side effects (libido/orgasm). It's hard to wean off of but I found that decreasing the dose very slowly helped. I could reduce to 50 mg with no problems and used that as my starting point. Then I would reduce the dosage by approximately 12.5 mg (by cutting the pills up) for each two-week stage. So it was 50 mg for 2 weeks, 37.5 mg for 2 weeks, 25 mg for 2 weeks,etc. I still had some dizziness but it wasn't quite as bad as when I followed the recommended protocol for weaning off!
1015$Depression$6/19/2012 6:34:21 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$This is the first anti depressant I ever took and my body's reaction to it should have been a warning for me against any meds. I took one pill, a very low dosage maybe 10mg, during a stay in a hospital psychiatric ward back in 2006. Soon after I began having very intense visual hallucinations. My doctor was notified at once and the medication stopped. He informed me that it was a rare, but serious, side effect of Zoloft and to never take it again because long term the hallucinations may become permanent. It seems my body is incredibly sensitive to psychiatric meds, especially anti depressants, as I have always had severe reactions to them. Eventually, I learned to work through my depression and anxiety and PTSD without the use of meds(therapy only) and am much happier now.

25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$2$4$"I have suffered from a mild form of depression since I was a teenager
column3: which I believe has been caused by being on various birth control pills.  I finally went off birth control several months ago and after a few months was still having significant PMDD
column4: so I finally submitted to being put on a Zoloft prescription. I took a low dose (50 mg) and it really helped me with anxiety and depression
column5: cutting the days of the month that I was depressed down from 5-7 to maybe a half a day or one day.

column2: I gained a LOT of weight (25 pounds in six months)
column3: despite working out 5-6 times a week and eating relatively healthy.  There were no changes in my diet or exercise
column4: the Zoloft was the only thing that could be causing it.  If it was just five or ten pounds I could handle it
column5: but I increased exercise and cut down on food intake and I was still gaining
column6: and my doctor told me that it is a commom side effect and it would probably be very difficult for me to lose the weight while still on the medication.

column1: I'm now weaning off the Zoloft because I want to try managing the depression with vitamins (first try will be fish oil and a B-complex).  I don't mean to sound vain but the weight gain was making me depressed as well as uncomfortable in my clothes and my own skin!

I hope this is helpful for someone who is considering taking Zoloft for PMDD - I think it's worth exhausting other options before getting on it because of the weight gain.  But if I don't find the vitamins and supplements helping I will get back on it
column2: I've had no other side effects from it besides some mild dizziness from time to time. "

column1:
1517$Depression$7/22/2010 12:39:55 PM$Reviewer: balancedbrain, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I am a 67 year old woman. Depression runs in my family. I have taken zoloft twice for depression in the last four years. (I do not suffer from anxiety attacks.) It has worked both times, though it takes awhile. The first few weeks it improves the quality of my sleep, and then it gradually lifts my mood until I am almost) my old cheery self. I am thankful for zoloft.  However, I have experienced some side effects:  first and foremost, diarrhea - which has slowed over time but still have some stomach irritation. (At one point the pharmacy switched generics and the diarrhea stopped completely.) Also, it has reduced my sex drive and ability to orgasm - my doc suggested I take a break from zoloft on the weekends and that has helped.(This could be a worse problem for younger couples with a more spontaneous sex life, but it works for us.) I have NOT experienced nausea, skin outbreaks, tremors. I am pleased with zoloft and feel fortunate that it has worked for me. It has helped my brother and my dad too. From reading the reviews, it seems that it is not as helpful for depression with anxiety. Also, I recommend patience when you first start taking it - it takes awhile to get the full benefit. I have recently added fish oil and aerobic exercise (Curves three days a week for 1/2 an hour) - and make sure I get as much light and sunshine as possible. It is important to socialize too - even if you have to force yourself. Good luck to all of you.

And it also helps me when the time of the month comes! I'm not a monster anymore as my husband would say! lol

column1: 1575$Depression$5/19/2010 10:09:32 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$Side effects lasted about a week and then were completely gone.  Worked great initially.  I became calm (no more flying off the handle) enjoyed my kids so much and they me and my social anxiety was mostly gone.  I stayed on it through my first 2 trimesters of pregnancy and went off for the last (had many panic attacks of feeling that I wasn't able to breathe
column2: partly because of pregnancy and magnified by stopping Zoloft cold turkey.)  Went back on it 3 weeks after daughter was born but it just never worked as well as it did previously.  I eventually started feeling very foggy and started having short term memory problems.  Adding 5htp and tyrosine helped.  The big thing too my appetite started getting out of control... thought about food constantly and craved sweets all the time which caused me to gain 10 lbs.  Went off of 50 mg cold turkey.  Have been off of it about 2.5 months.  Has been tough and very on and off.  Started taking 5htp and tyrosine and starting to feel more leveled out.  I read that long term Zoloft use can affect your metabolism.  I'm hoping I can lose some weight and won't hesitate to try antidepressants again if I really need them (hope I can lose some weight first though..) Great at first
column3: but long term can have a weight gain a foggy thinking effect. Eventually would probably have to be enhanced by Wellbutrin or Ambilify especially with the foggy thinking.

1633$Depression$4/1/2010 9:57:22 PM$Reviewer: equsole, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$Tried taking this several years ago when I was in my early twenties and it made my depression worse. I've been on several different antidepressants since then and when my last one stopped working I took some time off from antidepressants (about 7 months). My OB/GYN suggested Zoloft because it is the safest one to take for pregnancy (I'm not pregnant yet, but have been trying). Well, I took it for 3 days - started on 25mg and on the 4th day I woke up have a severe panic attack that lasted all morning. I decided not to take my dose that day and later in the evening I started having dizzy spells and visual disturbances (twinkling stars and black spots) followed by a migraine. Needless to say, I will no longer be taking Zoloft. Also, it is no worse or better to take during pregnancy than any other of the antidepressants available; like most antidepressants it is riskier to take it during the last trimester...and knowing how bad the withdrawal symptoms are for this drug, I would not think this is a good drug to take during a pregnancy. I am experimenting with herbal supplements right now - I highly recommend wild oat extract (from Bach), a raw B-vitamin complex, and fish oil extract (high quality).

column5: I experienced really bad anxiety
column6: like nothing I'd ever experienced before. It was as if a part of my mind was spinning out of control and I was helpless to do anything about it. column7: and I've dealt with varying degrees of anxiety for decades. But this was completely new to me and scared the living hell out of me.  After switching to Celexa
column8: my side effects almost immediately abated and my depression lifted within several weeks of therapy. So the moral of the story
column9: obviously
column10: is that everyone's brain receptors work differently
column11: there is no test to determine the best drugs for those receptors
column12: and so careful monitoring and switching of drugs when called for is the best and only course of action.

1774$Depression$12/20/2009 2:42:26 PM$Reviewer: HEYTHERE, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$I am 17 years old. I started using opiate painkillers at age 14 and injecting opiates iv including heroin when I was 16. I tried to get off of opiates for 6 months by myself and finally decided to see a shrink. I was very depressed without opiates scaled 8/10 and anxiety on a level of 11/10. The shrink put me on zolft 50 for withdrawls and did nothing the first 2 days. on the third day of taking zoloft I got terrible cold sweats (along with opiate withdrawl cold sweats), and was sleeping less then before. I began getting 2 hours of sleep max, and I felt like a zombie. about 5 days after I stoped opiates, and started zoloft I started on suboxone (which is specifically for opiate withdrawls). my depression seemed to get better but I was still a zombie and was still very anxious. I stopped taking zolft after about a month and just taking suboxone. my depression and anxiety disapeared aswell as my night sweats and sleep problems. but the withdrawls from zolft were very scary and would creep up on me. all of the sudded I would get a crazy tingle down my arms and through my hands, I would get these 'brain zaps'like an electrical shock through my brain where I would blurt weird noises unintentionally. I would get about 10 'brain zaps' a day and were very very frightening. the brain zaps slowly disapated but I stil get them when falling asleep maybe once or twice a week. I have been off zolft for 2 months now and i am still having withdrawls. I will never take an anti-depressant again EVER! Beware of this med. YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR!

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$Great drug. It took 2 months to take full effect.  I am currently on 100mg in the morning plus clanezapam at .25mg in the morning and afternoon.  My depression kicked in the summer of 2008 when I moved to a new home and started a high stress job that I did not choose.  On top of that I was diagnosed with a heart condition that will most likely result in a valve replacement surgery down the road. I also went through about 2-3 months of therapy.  I am a totally different person today.  I was never socially active and I was having frequent panic attacks.  It is strange when you look back at it how you are in a deep hole and you fear that you will never get your life back.  I have gotten my life back with the help of Zoloft.  I highly recommend it to anyone suffering the same issues. You have to have faith and belief that you will overcome your depression.  It was hard at first getting out to do normal everyday things.  I forced myself to get out and do chores outside and my family was a great help.  I did try other drugs at first and Zoloft was my life saver. I plan an taking the rest of my life because I never want to be the person I was before
column3: always anxious and never wanting to be around other people.

25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$3$5$"This is a great drug for depression and anxiety but if you ever want to have a orgasm again without popping a vessel in your head by trying so hard
column3: good luck. I took 100mg of Zoloft for seven years and for the most part felt great. The only side affect for me was how my doctor put it ""I couldn't get mt ticket punched during sex"". This simply would not do for me. Coming off the drug is difficult but can be done. Just ween yourself each week you are taking it to smaller doses by cutting the pills. You will get an strong feeling of dizziness and disorientation but it does pass within a short time. Maybe 2 weeks or so. Once u get past that point u will be fine. I now take Wellbutrin which does everything the Zoloft did minus the sexual side affect. Good luck people and if u want off this drug it isn't easy but it can be done. Just hang in there. I'm really proud of everyone who are taking steps to make their life happy and fulfilling for them and their family.

column1: Oh one other thing...If u decide to switch drugs from one that isn't working for you to another you and your doctor want to try
column2: it was my experience to ween yourself off the first drug a little before starting the new one. I told my doctor about my side affects with Zoloft and he immediately wanted me to start Celexa without getting some of the Zoloft about of my system....HUGE MISTAKE...don't do this...Cut your Zoloft dosage down to almost nothing then start the new one. When he had me just switch from one to the other within a day that really screwed me up. Just a word of advice.

column1: 1912$Depression$9/24/2009 6:48:43 PM$Reviewer: oldthymegal, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I have been taking Zoloft for 16 years for severe clinical depression

column3: also have had weight gain. But overall
column4: I have had excellent results with this medicine.  Have tried generics - some work pretty well
column5: some don't. They all have different ""fillers"" in them
column6: and some pharmacies (especially the big mail-order one) do tend to buy the cheapest ones. I got one (made by Cobalt out of Canada) that I was actually allergic to.  It also had absolutely no effect as far as controlling my depression - I cried for 2 weeks on it - went back to brand Zoloft and was better in 2 days.  So if you have to take generic for insurance reasons be sure you get it from a reputable pharmacy and ask them what generics they use(there are lots for Zoloft).  When you find one that works for you
column7: ask your doctor to always specify that particular generic when he writes your prescription. Best advice is to get a generic from a US company
column8: as quality control standards are monitored better here. My experience has been that brand Zoloft is best
column9: and it's worth the additional cost if you can manage it. I believe this medicine has been God's way of healing me from depression so that I can live a productive life
column10: and I am grateful for it.    "

column1: 2115$Depression$6/5/2009 4:57:37 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $2$1$4$"I was prescribed Zoloft at 17. I took it for depression up until a few months ago. I’m turning 32 next week. Just to make that point perfectly clear
column2: that it’s been 15 years.?

column1: I stopped Zoloft for about a year in 2003. At this point
column2: I weaned off of 75mgs over the course of a month. I experienced all the typical withdrawal symptoms (both verified and unverified by the drug companies). These included “brain zaps”
column3: faintness
column4: nausea
column5: severe rage/aggression (almost violent)
column6: crying fits
column7: etc…  The withdrawal symptoms went away after about six months. I noticed that my compulsion to drink alcohol went away (and therefore the weight that I had gained)
column8: as did the zombie feeling. I had been on this for so long that I thought it was all normal! I actually started to feel things again
column9: sans “Garden State”. I actually wanted to experience life.

column2: I had to start taking it again within a year due to unexpected hardships. Within weeks of taking Zoloft again
column3: the zombie like existence returned
column4: as did the compulsion to drink
column5: weight gain
column6: etc. At this point
column7: I realized for the first time that it was the drug that made me feel this way (crazy how it distorts your thinking).

column1: I stayed on Zoloft for another six years because I was terrified of the withdrawal
column2: and what it would do to my job and personal life if I tried to stop again.

column1: I finally stopped taking Zoloft again about a month ago. I suppose being laid off is as good at time as any to kick a bad habit. ? I followed the same process for weaning of it. I had the exact same symptoms as the last time; “brain zaps”
column2: faintness
column3: nausea
column4: severe aggression (almost violent)
column5: crying fits
column6: etc. I’ve been off it for two months now
column7: and I still have all the withdrawal symptoms. I don’t
column8: however
column9: have the “zombified” feeling
column10: compulsion to drink alcohol
column11: negative sexual side effects
column12: or lack of interest in daily activities that used to accompany Zoloft for the last 15 years.

column1: In the two Zoloft free months I have; been i"

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$4$5$"I've been taking Zoloft for over 10 years at 100mg.  It has really helped me with depression which runs in my family.  Here are some things to know:

column1: - Everyone reacts differently.  Just because someone had a negative experience on this board does not mean you will.  I did not experience nausea
column2: anxiety
column3: sleeplessness or lethargy.  Others have.

column1: - Start out slowly.  Your doc should put you on a lower dosage and slowly increase it over time.  This helps your body get used to it with less side effects.
- Be patient...it takes 2-3 weeks to kick in.  So you might not feel any benefit until much later on.
- It doesn't change who you are.  That was my fear.  I didn't want a happy pill.  It did lift my depression so I saw things more clearly.  I am still the same person. However
column2: if you had life problems before this pill won't make them go away.  It will help you to deal with them for effectively by making you functional."

column2: even compared to other SSRIs.  It took about a month to really start working once I began taking it.  The drug is a very effective libido suppressor but has not caused any other major side effects in use.  However
column3: if you can plan ahead and skip a dose before having sex
column4: one can overcome the libido problem without having adverse effects upon the depression.  Dose reduction and withdrawl does need to be done very slowly
column5: over a period of several months.  When I reduced the dose too fast
column6: I ended up with a bad depressive episode
column7: though I knew why and was able to cope with it. Restoration to the original dose reversed the problem in a few days.  Missing more than a couple of doses in a row also caused some of the strangest dreams I've ever had.  Not bad

column9: one needs to be careful taking the generic version of this drug.  The first generic version of the drug I took

column11: felt like I was taking about 2/3 of my dose.  After switching to a different generic version
column12: a larger oval shaped pill

column1: 2837$Depression$2/11/2008 5:29:04 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$Zoloft worked very well for easing the symptoms of my postpartum depression. I was on a relatively low dose

I felt good
column3: not depressed
column4: but at the same time my normally happy/hyperactive personality was toned way down. I didn't realize how much I missed it until I came off the medication and started feeling really happy and fun again.

2866$Depression$1/24/2008 11:02:29 AM$Reviewer: KathyM, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$4$My Doctor prescribed Zoloft for me after being severely stressed out and i was also on Xanax. I've been on Zoloft for 2 months and i did notice some restless nights at first but have no trouble now.
I am on a low dose but after a couple weeks i did notice that things were not as upsetting to me and seemed happier.
Three weeks ago my father died suddenly and if not for the medications i was already on i think my depression would have had a devastating effect on me.

I did notice that if i didnt take my zoloft for 3 days i had a sudden change in mood. I thought that by being more stable in my life i wouldnt need the Zoloft but i couldnt explain the sudden mood change to depressing thoughts. I immediately took the Zoloft that night and have felt ok since.
As for the loss of sex drive
column2: i think i have noticed a change but i have a wonderful relationship now and we still have regular sex although i do notice it is difficult for me to achieve an orgasm.

column1: At first i was afraid to take Zoloft from all the reviews i read but now i am grateful for it. It has definitely helped me thru a very rough time in my life.

2879$Depression$1/12/2008 6:10:06 PM$Reviewer: kathyd, 45-54 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$Tried Efexor, Cymbalta, and Lexipro prior to finding ZOLOFT - had BAD experiences with all of them (nausea, respiratory issues, dizziness, rapid heartbeat, vomiting, etc.) Tried Z. and no side effects at all - my moods became better, i was much more patient, I was able to have a conversation without crying jags (post menopausal for 2 years)Much better adjusted at work and not so argumentative and angry all the time - ALSO, able to sleep at night for first time in 5 years!However, have been on 50mg a day and do experience these: night sweats (possibly from menopause), gained 10 pounds in 3 months (once I start to eat, I can't seem to stop (this goes for drinking, too), also had one experience at work where completely lost it and threw things and walked off the job. Complete melt-down. But all in all, I'd say it was a successful treatment strategy - overall am very happy with the drug, I will just start a diet!

column2: I certainly can see we all have different metabolisms--thats why it's important to have a trustworthy and competent dr. overseeing ones treatment. A chemical imbalance is ultimately responsible for a lot of our symptoms. Apprehension about seeking help is our 1st hurdle. We shouldn't let a bad experience with any (1) drug or type of drug deter us from finding relief.  I myself
column3: need to change my medication usually annually. (apparently I build up a tolerance). As I sense it happening
column4: I freely and openly discuss with my personal physician and we either have tried a different med. or upped dosage at times. Over the last 8yrs. we have found that going back and forth between Paxil and Zoloft works best for my metabolism. Prozac and Climadyn weren't well tolerated (got worse).

column2: in conclusion
column3: I like to say don't give up--you don't have to live life being depressed
column4: anxious etc.. but it may take a few tries to find what chemical may be active
column5: inactive
column6: overactive in your system.

column1: KISS - KEEP IT(life) SIMPLE SWEETY!   p.s. someday our dna will enable us to quickly and absolutely know what our bodies are in need of
column2: in excess of
column3: etc.. until then its trial and error
column4: and my dr. I've chosen to trust.  My own knowledge isn't always enough.  Again seek help if you are having depression

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$2$4$"I took this medication at 100 mg for 2 years. It worked great in the since that I was made emotionally flat. Unlike other SSRI medications I was stable on it though.

column1: I went from a severe fluctuation between manic and depressive moods to being calm. Eventually I had no motivation to improve myself and was slowly wasting away. I would have been okay with every ending or just continuing as it was with no preference.

After getting off the drug my mood cycles are now very numbed and no longer effect my daily life. While weaning off the drug I was thrown back into a manic depressive hyperactive state. I got back on it and weaned off again 6 months later with success. Ever since I have had a low libido and tend to not want to do anything social.
